questions.question: What is the role of a 'Moderator' (such as heavy water or graphite) in a nuclear fission reactor?
options: To cool down the reactor core to prevent melting.
To slow down fast-moving neutrons so they are more likely to be captured by fuel nuclei.
To absorb all neutrons and stop the reaction.
To increase the speed of the alpha particles.
questions.explanation: Moderators: H₂O, D₂O, graphite, beryllium. Slow neutrons from ~2 MeV (fission) to ~0.025 eV (thermal). U-235 fission cross-section for thermal neutrons ~585 barns vs. ~1 barn for fast neutrons. Slowing increases probability of fission vs. capture.

questions.question: Which of the following equations represents a typical nuclear fusion reaction occurring in a star?
questions.explanation: D-T fusion: Deuterium ($^2$H) + Tritium ($^3$H) → Helium-4 + neutron + 17.6 MeV. Main candidate for terrestrial fusion. In stars: proton-proton chain ($4^1\text{H} → ^4\text{He} + 2e^+ + 2\nu_e + 26.7\text{MeV}$) dominates in Sun-like stars.

questions.question: In a fission chain reaction, if the 'Multiplication Factor' ($k$) is exactly 1.0, the reactor is said to be:
options: Critical (the reaction is stable and self-sustaining).
questions.explanation: $k = \text{(neutrons in generation n+1)} / \text{(neutrons in generation n)}$. $k<1$: subcritical (decays), $k=1$: critical (steady power), $k>1$: supercritical (increasing power). Reactors operate at $k=1$, controlled by control rods adjusting neutron absorption.

questions.question: What is the primary reason why nuclear fusion is not yet a viable source for commercial power plants?
options: There is not enough hydrogen on Earth to fuel it.
It produces more dangerous waste than fission.
It requires more energy to contain the plasma than the reaction currently produces (the 'break-even' problem).
It is impossible to stop once it starts.
questions.explanation: Lawson criterion: $nT\tau > 3\times10^{21}\ \text{keV·s·m}^{-3}$ for D-T. Q = fusion power/input power. Currently: Q~0.67 (JET, 1997). ITER goal: Q≥10. Challenges: plasma instability, heat management, neutron damage to materials.

questions.question: Which of the following particles is released in large quantities during fission and is responsible for the 'Chain' part of a chain reaction?
questions.explanation: Fission neutrons: prompt (released immediately) and delayed (from fission fragments). Average ~2.5 neutrons per U-235 fission. Neutrons sustain chain by inducing more fissions. Neutrinos weakly interacting, not useful for chain reaction.

questions.question: In the Binding Energy curve, why does fusion stop being exothermic (releasing energy) once it reaches Iron-56?
options: Iron is too soft to fuse.
Nuclei heavier than Iron have a lower binding energy per nucleon, so fusing them would require an input of energy.
Iron is a liquid in the center of stars.
questions.explanation: Fe-56 peak: ~8.8 MeV/nucleon. Fusion beyond iron (e.g., Fe + He → Ni) requires energy input → endothermic. Only occurs in extreme environments (supernova shockwaves, neutron star mergers). This creates elements heavier than iron.

questions.question: 'Magnetic Confinement' and 'Inertial Confinement' are the two main methods scientists use to attempt:
questions.explanation: Magnetic: tokamaks (ITER), stellarators use magnetic fields to contain plasma (10⁸ K). Inertial: lasers (NIF) or particle beams compress fuel pellet rapidly. Both aim to achieve conditions for net energy gain (Q>1).

questions.question: What happens to the total mass of the system during a fusion reaction?
options: A small amount of mass is converted into a large amount of energy.
The mass doubles because two nuclei are joining.
questions.explanation: $E = \Delta m c^2$. D-T fusion: initial mass = 5.03015 u (D + T), final = 5.01127 u (He + n), $\Delta m = 0.01888$ u → 17.6 MeV. Mass defect = binding energy increase. ~0.7% mass converted to energy.

questions.question: Which of the following is a byproduct of the fusion of Deuterium ($^2\text{H}$) and Tritium ($^3\text{H}$)?
questions.explanation: D + T → $^4$He (3.5 MeV) + n (14.1 MeV). Neutron carries 80% of energy. In reactor: neutron captured in lithium blanket to breed tritium ($n + ^6\text{Li} → ^4\text{He} + ^3\text{H}$) and produce heat for electricity.

questions.question: 'Enrichment' of Uranium is the process of increasing the concentration of which isotope to make it suitable for fission?
questions.explanation: Natural uranium: 0.72% U-235 (fissile), 99.27% U-238 (fertile). Light water reactors need ~3-5% enrichment. Methods: gas centrifugation, gaseous diffusion, laser separation. U-238 can breed Pu-239 in breeder reactors.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! Mastery of advanced fission and fusion concepts including reactor components (moderators, control rods), chain reaction kinetics (multiplication factor), confinement methods, energy balance challenges, and isotope engineering.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Strong understanding of advanced nuclear processes. Review: 1) Moderator vs. control rod functions, 2) Criticality definitions ($k<1, =1, >1$), 3) Fusion confinement methods, 4) Binding energy curve beyond iron, 5) Uranium enrichment and fusion fuel cycles.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) How moderators and control rods regulate reactors, 2) Critical mass and multiplication factor, 3) Why fusion is harder than fission to achieve, 4) Fusion reaction products and energy, 5) Uranium enrichment purpose.
scoreMessages.0: Start with basics: Review fission chain reaction control mechanisms, the challenges of achieving controlled fusion on Earth, and how both processes relate to the binding energy per nucleon curve.
